author: sky.cactus
content: I'm concerned about the pattern of calling "Ether held on an L2 ETH" because I have a strong suspicion that once L2s are common, we'll see a *lot* of users sending L2 ETH to places that only accept L1 ETH or only accept certain L2 ETH.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think we (community) should really strive to label L2 ETH and tokens uniquely, and not call them by the same name when they are on different networks.

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, you may have Arbitrum-ETH or Arbitrum-USDC, but you don't have ETH on Arbitrum.

author: sky.cactus
content: Then when someone says, "send me ETH" it is explicit that they mean "send me L1 native ETH" which is different from "send me WETH" or "send me Arbitrum ETH".

author: sky.cactus
content: Various L2s can perhaps come up with short terms/symbols for their L2's, maybe it is `ARBI-ETH`  or something.

author: treyzania
content: I asked a while back if there was anyone working on standardization for rollup-aware address or payment url formats or anything of that nature

author: treyzania
content: I didn't hear anything about it but if cross-rollup swaps (hop, etc.) become popular and multi rollup wallets work well it's probably something that would go a long way to improve usability

author: sky.cactus
content: I *think* that is a separate problem.  There are some situations where you have a payment URL that you can open in your wallet.  There are *other* situations where someone just says "send me ETH, here is my address" (no payment URL).

author: sky.cactus
content: It is the latter that I'm worried is going to have a lot of confusion if we call L2 Ether "ETH".
